channel.title: visualization on Tomas' Visualization Blog
channel.description: Recent content in visualization on Tomas' Visualization Blog

item.title: Change in the Volume of Real Estate for Sale in Finland from 2018 to 2022
item.description: This post shows how the real estate market in Finland changed in terms of volume in years 2018-2022. Data I work with a dataset of rental ads that I scraped from Google search cache between October 2017 and January 2022. It’s by far not complete, but it’s representative enough. The displayed volume is amount of apartments, row houses, pair houses and family houses for sale. It includes all the forms of ownership.

item.title: Growth of Rental Prices in Tampere in the last 3 Years
item.description: In cities, the price of real estate is growing since ever. The rental prices should follow the selling prices. In this post I explore how the rental prices of apartments in Tamere grew in the last 3 years (2018, 2019, 2020), and I find subsets of the rental items, which show different rate of growth, e.g. expensive apartments vs cheap apartments, small apartments vs large apartments, apartments in different neighborhoods.

item.title: Price of Rental Apartments in Tampere
item.description: In this post, I will explore and show how various features of an apartment (age, location, year built) affect rental price in the city of Tampere. I hope it will be interesting for someone who’s renting (or letting), to understand the situation better. I will not explore price development over time in this post, but I will write another one on the topic. Data I work with a dataset of rental ads that I scraped from Google search cache in 2018, 2019 and 2020.

item.title: Rich Boxplot
item.description: It’s often useful to visually understand how one statistic relates to another. For example, to see how rental apartment area affects its monthly price. The first visualization that would come to my mind is scatter plot, and I argue that scatter plot is not descriptive enough to offer good understanding of the simple case of two 1d statistics. I propose a rich boxplot visualization that gives better overview of the correlation to the reader.

item.title: About Me
item.description: I am a freelance IT professional, and besides visualization I focus on Golang development and infrastructure automation (DevOps?). In past I worked in Google in Dublin, in CERN in Geneva, I did contract work for Basho, the makers of Riak, and Rovio, the company behind the Angry Birds. I wrote Ansible modules for the Packet host (acquired by Equinix in 2020 and rebranded as Equinix Metal). I am maintaining Equinix Metal Terraform Provider and a couple of other intrastructure-related Golang-based tools.

item.title: About This Site
item.description: I will try to publish interesting data visualizations on this site. In 2017 I was buying my first apartment and, even though it was the biggest purchase of my life, I realized I have very weak overview of the real estate market. Thinking about it in this way was very scary. I imagine many people go through this process, and end up relying on tribal knowlegde of the real estate agents and intuition.
